title: Organization
description: The organization(s) involved in the incident. At least one organization, the victim organization, should be included as part of an incident bundle. There may be other organizations involved, such as a competitor organization that benefitted from stolen data or pass through organization that received kickbacks. The victim organization(s) include all organizations negatively impacted by the incident, not just the organization(s) that employed the insider. An organization may have one or more jobs. An organization may have one or more stressors. An organization may have one or more relationships with other organizations.

id.description: A unique string that begins with "organization--" and is appended with a UUIDv4.

name.description: The name of the organization. E.g., "Company XYZ, Inc."

city.description: The city where the organization is located. Use the address of the headquarters if the whole organization was affected or use the address of the local branch if only that local branch was affected.

state.description: The state where the organization is located. Use the address of the headquarters if the whole organization was affected or use the address of the local branch if only that local branch was affected.

country.description: The country where the organization is located. Use the address of the headquarters if the whole organization was affected or use the address of the local branch if only that local branch was affected. Public implementations should use the standard codes provided by ISO 3166-1 alpha-2.

postal_code.description: The postal code of the organization. Use the address of the headquarters if the whole organization was affected or use the address of the local branch if only that local branch was affected.

small_business.description: TRUE if the organization is a privately owned business with 500 or fewer employees.

industry_sector.description: Top level category for the economic sector the organization belongs to. Note, sectors are dervied from the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) version 2022 published by the United States Office of Management and Budget.

industry_subsector.description: Second level category for the economic sector the organization belongs to. This value MUST map back to industry_sector. E.g., if sector is "9", subsector must be "9.x"

parent_company.description: Name of the organization's parent company, if applicable.

incident_role.description: The organization's role in the incident.

oneOf.title: Agriculture and Mining
oneOf.description: Growing crops, raising animals, harvesting timber, or extraction of naturally occurring minerals.

oneOf.title: Mining, Quarrying, and Oil and Gas Extraction
oneOf.description: Establishments that extract naturally occurring mineral solids, liquid minerals, and gases, to include quarrying, well operations, beneficiating, and other preparation customarily performed at the mine site, or as a part of mining activity.

oneOf.title: Utilities
oneOf.description: Provisioning of services for the public (e.g., energy, water, and waste collection).

oneOf.title: Construction
oneOf.description: Construction and engineering of buildings and associated support services or trades.

oneOf.title: Manufacturing
oneOf.description: Mechanical, Chemical, Physical changes to material.

oneOf.title: Wholesale Trade
oneOf.description: The exchange of goods and services.

oneOf.title: Retail Trade
oneOf.description: The exchange of goods and services.

oneOf.title: Transportation and Warehousing
oneOf.description: Services directly or indirectly involved in the movement of people.

oneOf.title: Information
oneOf.description: Hardware or software systems related to the processing, communications, and accessing of information.

oneOf.title: Finance and Insurance
oneOf.description: Financial services, payment processors, and insurance.

oneOf.title: Real Estate and Rental/Leasing
oneOf.description: Property sales and renting/leasing of assets.

oneOf.title: Professional Services, Scientific and Technical Services
oneOf.description: Services provided by trained professionals in specialized fields.

oneOf.title: Management of Companies and Enterprises
oneOf.description: Establishments that administer, oversee, and manage may hold the securities of the company or enterprise.

oneOf.title: Administrative and Support and Waste Management and Remediation Services
oneOf.description: Establishments performing routine support activities for the day-to-day operations of other organizations.

oneOf.title: Arts, Entertainment, Recreation
oneOf.description: Industries that meet the entertainment needs of patrons.

oneOf.title: Public Administration
oneOf.description: Federal/State/Local administration and the oversight of public programs.

oneOf.title: Other
oneOf.description: Other sector not listed in this vocabulary.

oneOf.title: Crop Production
oneOf.description: Industries in the Crop Production subsector grow crops mainly for food and fiber. The subsector comprises establishments, such as farms, orchards, groves, greenhouses, and nurseries, primarily engaged in growing crops, plants, vines, or trees and their seeds.

oneOf.title: Animal Production and Aquaculture
oneOf.description: Industries in the Animal Production and Aquaculture subsector raise or fatten animals for the sale of animals or animal products and/or raise aquatic plants and animals in controlled or selected aquatic environments for the sale of aquatic plants, animals, or their products. The subsector includes establishments, such as ranches, farms, and feedlots, primarily engaged in keeping, grazing, breeding, or feeding animals.

oneOf.title: Forestry and Logging
oneOf.description: Industries in the Forestry and Logging subsector grow and harvest timber on a long production cycle (i.e., of 10 years or more).

oneOf.title: Fishing, Hunting and Trapping
oneOf.description: Industries in the Fishing, Hunting and Trapping subsector harvest fish and other wild animals from their natural habitats and are dependent upon a continued supply of the natural resource.

oneOf.title: Support Activities for Agriculture and Forestry
oneOf.description: Industries in the Support Activities for Agriculture and Forestry subsector provide support services that are an essential part of agricultural and forestry production. These support activities may be performed by the agriculture or forestry producing establishment or conducted independently as an alternative source of inputs required for the production process for a given crop, animal, or forestry industry.

oneOf.title: Electrical Equipment, Appliance, and Component Manufacturing
Building Material and Garden Equipment and Supplies Dealers
Furniture, Home Furnishings, Electronics, and Appliance Retailers
Clothing, Clothing Accessories, Shoe, and Jewelry Retailers
Sporting Goods, Hobby, Musical Instrument, Book, and Miscellaneous Retailers
Motion Picture and Sound Recording Industries
Computing Infrastructure Providers, Data Processing, Web Hosting, and Related Services
Web Search Portals, Libraries, Archives, and Other Information Services
Securities, Commodity Contracts, and Other Financial Investments and Related Activities
Funds, Trusts, and Other Financial Vehicles
Lessors of Nonfinancial Intangible Assets (except Copyrighted Works)
Performing Arts, Spectator Sports, and Related Industries
Museums, Historical Sites, and Similar Institutions
Religious, Grantmaking, Civic, Professional, and Similar Organizations
Executive, Legislative, and Other General Government Support
Justice, Public Order, and Safety Activities
Administration of Housing Programs, Urban Planning, and Community Development
National Security
oneOf.description: This industry comprises government establishments of the Armed Forces, including the National Guard, primarily engaged in national security and related activities.

oneOf.title: International Affairs
oneOf.description: This industry comprises establishments of U.S. and foreign governments primarily engaged in international affairs and programs relating to other nations and peoples.

oneOf.title: Beneficiary
oneOf.description: The organization accepted trade secrets, customer lists, intellectual property, etc. that the insider obtained through the incident.

oneOf.title: Primary Victim
oneOf.description: The organization was the primary victim organization of the insider's actions.

oneOf.title: Secondary Victim
oneOf.description: The organization was a secondary victim to the incident. E.g., An organization that relied on the primary victim's services in order to conduct their business.

oneOf.title: Trusted Business Partner
oneOf.description: The organization has an alliance (contractually, bonded, etc.) with the victim organization.

oneOf.title: Other
oneOf.description: Other role not described by this vocabulary.
